Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Building a Starting Core for No-Boundary Education and Research Network

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The team proposes a new concept of "No-Boundary Thinking (NBT)", which emerged from an NSF EPSCoR-supported Workshop in Bioinformatics at Little Rock, Arkansas in 2013, as well as follow-on meetings and discussions. The aim is to build a starting core to further explore no-boundary thinking in education and research through an innovative network of universities and projects. No-boundary thinking will be the key connection among a distributed set of researchers, students and science challenges. This project is a joint effort of 24 faculty members from 19 institutions from 13 states, with the represented research areas including fundamental life sciences, biology, agriculture, biophysics, biochemistry, engineering, computer science, mathematics, and statistics.

The focus of NBT is no-boundary problem defining. The goal is to educate and train students with NBT through development of a "No-Boundary Education and Research Network". The team will Identify 3-4 no-boundary research problems for which current interdisciplinary research or bigdata approaches do not work well and apply no-boundary thinking in problem defining. The focus is problem defining, not just problem solving. Then, students will learn with a no-boundary thinking approach through research projects and problems, which should lead to an understanding of the roles of data, approaches, and infrastructure/High Performance Computing in problem defining and solving, and provide them with opportunities to learn to integrate data collection, approach design, and infrastructure to address scientific research challenges. Outreach will include a national meeting to discuss the impacts of current interdisciplinary research and big-data to science and education, and how to further promote NBT nationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF EAGER grant (2014-2020) greatly supports the effort of a national network group promoting the concept of No-Boundary Thinking (NBT) in research and education nation-wide. PI conceived the concept, "No-Boundary Thinking is no-boundary problem defining on time-chain to address real science challenges". It is different from current multi-, inter- or trans-disciplinary, or the NSF Convergence. No-Boundary Thinking is the key connection between researchers and science real challenges. The NBT national network started with 30 members of the Steering Committee representing institutions from about 16 states, with the represented research areas including fundamental life sciences, biology, biomedicine, public health, agriculture, physics, chemistry, engineering, computer science, mathematics, and statistics. 

Especially, based on No-Boundary Thinking (NBT), PI founded the Arkansas Artificial Intelligence (AI) Campus, a state-wide free training program currently involving eight Arkansas Institutions; and founded the Joint Translational Research Lab on the campuses of Arkansas State University and St. Bernard’s Medical Center’s Internal Medicine Residency Program. In 2020, the Center for No-Boundary Thinking (CNBT) at Arkansas State University, as the first NBT center nationwide, was established with the approval of the Arkansas Higher Education Coordinating Board.

The NBT network group published three papers related to the NBT concept (Huang et al. 2013; Huang et al. 2015; Moore et al. 2017). The members of the network group have generated many collaborative research projects and publications in different areas. The network group hosted seminars and offered courses for undergraduate, graduate students and interested faculty members at their institutions and virtually accessible for other institutions. The group is planning to extend the Arkansas AI-Campus effort to a National AI-Campus to advance research, education and training. The group hosted 10 NBT meetings and workshops at various locations provided opportunities in research and education, which drew a large number of students, faculty, and researchers from different disciplines throughout Arkansas and nation-wide.
